author: Siobhan McFadyen
title: NASA's Mars Curiosity Rover beams back footage of giant crater on Red Planet which contained ancient lakes
text:
The Martian crater currently being explored by the Nasa rover once contained lakes that remained for up to 10,000 years at a time - long enough to support life, say experts.
The images show evidence of sediments transported southward by shallow streams to the boundary of an ancient lake.
Experts at California Institute of Technology have been pouring over incredible data discoveries from the second smallest planet in the Solar System following discoveries made by NASA's robot geologist Curiosity rover which landed on the planet in 2012.
PA Red planet: The planet Mars in an image taken by the ISRO Mars Orbiter Mission spacecraft
Rock formations snapped by the robot suggest that long ago a transient water system of deltas and lakes dominated the landscape of Gale Crater.
Scientists estimated that over time individual lakes at this location may have persisted for between 100 and 10,000-year-long periods.
"This is potentially long enough for primitive life to establish itself in the crater," said the Curiosity team led by Professor John Grotzinger from the California Institute of Technology at Pasadena.
PA Deep impact: this 461km crater named after astronomer Giovanni Schiaparelli is located near Mars' equator
Writing in the journal Science, the researchers concluded : "One of the key criteria for planetary habitability is the duration for which water might have been accessible to enable microbial origination and evolution.
"The Gale crater floor today is the lowest topographic depression for over 1,000 kilometres in any direction, including the northern plains.
"Our results show that water pooled there, in surface and subsurface reservoirs, for a geologically and perhaps biologically relevant period of time ."
